commit_message:
Update cached LXC image in place

The LXC container creation playbook is one of the longest-running playbooks
in the repository.  It generally takes 15-17 minutes to run during the gate
jobs.  Much of this time is spent updating each container with the latest
packages.

This patch causes the LXC cached image to be updated one time before that
image is used for all of the containers.  It reduces the amount of times the
updates actually run and this shortens the time it takes to complete the
playbook.

The updates to the cached image will only occur if a new cache image has
just been downloaded.

subject: Release resources allocated to the Instance when it gets deleted
commit_message:
Release resources allocated to the Instance when it gets deleted

Currently when application get deleted its servers are also get deleted,
but all underlying allocated OpenStack resources remain so.

This commit makes the following to happen upon deletion:
* Exclude OS::Nova::Server resource from the stack
* Exclude all FloatingIP and related resources allocated for the server
* Exclude Neutron ports allocated to the server
* Exclude all Heat Software Configs (in case of HeatSWConfigInstance)
   created by the app
* Exclude all HOT template outputs related to deleted resources

Also:
* Instance class gets releaseResources method that can be used by apps to explicitly
  destroy the server. It can be recreated later again using deploy method
* The order in which .destroy() methods get called was changed so that the owner's
   destructor be called before that of the owned object. For example application
   destructor will be executed prior to its Instance destructor. This allows application
   to delete all references to the server that is going to be destroyed. Thus Heat template
   remains consistent.

Closes-Bug: #1499563

subject: Convert AutoScalingGroup adjustments to handle_signal
commit_message:
Convert AutoScalingGroup adjustments to handle_signal

Currently, we use a non-standard adjust() interface to couple the
ScalingPolicy and AutoScalingGroup resources.  It's better if we
move towards a consistent model where all asychronous inter-resource
signalling uses the standard handle_signal plugin API, for the following
reasons:
- Better scalability and better for convergence architecture due to less
  coupled resources (because the signal can be sent via RPC in future).
- Better for debuggability and operators, because ASG adjustments can
  be triggered via heat resource-signal
- We can more easily allow the native and AWS-compatible implementations
  to diverge, when we only use standard plugin interfaces.
- Easier interfacing with non-policy actors for triggering ASG adjustments
  for example, having mistral drive scaling adjustments via workflow.

Note at the moment we don't make the ASG resources SignalResponder's,
and we don't expose a URL for them.  This is because Ceilometer currently
gives us no control over the alarm post body, so we need an intermdiate
ScalingPolicy resource to enable adjustment context to be added to the
signal.  This doesn't preclude developer/operator (or even mistral) signalling
via heat resource-signal, it's just means you can't directly define signal
relationships triggering the ASG adjustment inside the templates yet.

Change-Id: I7c5cd627277906509fb794a3090625e9b459a760

subject: Revert "Deprecate cinder.cross_az_attach option"
commit_message:
Revert "Deprecate cinder.cross_az_attach option"

This reverts commit d8d2f02f3014e8d7e0ef9a61723f5a10f050cc81

The deprecation change was merged before operators had a
chance to weigh in and it turns out that at least one large
operator relies on this option for isolating VMs and volumes
to the same availability zones.

There are still a lot of issues around the usage of this
option and the tightly coupled interaction between nova
and cinder with respect to availability zones.  We need
to better document this option and how it's used which
will come in a follow up change.

We also need to address the usability issues around this
when doing a boot from volume where source != volume,
because right now the failure happens when building the
VM and that results in a NoValidHost error for the user
if they didn't specify the request correctly or their
admin doesn't have the cloud configured correctly.

Ultimately there is a lot of API policy defined between
this option and the allow_availability_zone_fallback
option in cinder and that's hidden from the user. So there
will probably also be a follow up change to add validation
in the compute API in the boot from volume case where
source != volume and cinder.cross_az_attach=False so
we can attempt to fail fast with a 400 response rather
than get to the compute node and fail the build.

There is related discussion in the mailing list here:

https://www.mail-archive.com/openstack-dev@lists.openstack.org/msg64179.html
